comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I'd say that this is another pic involving the February 1936 Meeks-Hordern wedding. Read all about it in the various Women's Weekly articles - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46942769.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Sorry no, Quasymody, the dress is 1926-1930. We do have a photograph of the wedding reception of Dinah Hordern and Harry Meeks at: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=823987&am... By 1936, the long dress and large hat was de riguer for bridesmaids. The wedding above is clearly pretty posh so it is possibly at Pitt Street Presbyterian Church.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Woops! Yeah, I'm not up to speed on fashions.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales

comment._content: Also the presence of Police means it's no ordinary wedding
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Weddings must have been a spectator sport in Sydney in the 1920s. Check out the crowds at the wedding of visiting Italian opera stars Toti dal Monte and Enzo de Muro Lomanto, which took place in Sydney in August 1928! - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16488771 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16488804 ; If anyone is interested, the SLNSW has a rather nice pic of Toti dal Monte - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=447324 ; There's also a good quality pic of Toti dal Monte's wedding party in the Sydney society magazine "The Home", 1 September, 1928, p. 20b.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: P.P.P.S. One point I've overlooked so far is that the bloke in the suit casting a critical eye in this direction looks remarkably like photographer Harold Cazneaux (sans moustache...he didn't always sport one from what I can make out) - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an12148506 ; If this were Cazneaux, then there's a good chance that one of his pics of this wedding might turn up somewhere, eg. in the society magazine "The Home", where many of his pics appeared in the later 1920s. Where I hang out I don't have access to a complete collection of "The Home", but given I've drawn a blank on this pic searching the digitised newspapers, that's where I'd start looking next if I could. I'm convinced that this crowd engaged the same milliner and florist who did the honours at this March 1928 Fairfax-Wilson wedding - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16452683 ; I'm even more convinced that the location is St James' Church, King Street. The columns match up, as do the stairs, and the square doorway and lintel - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an2345957

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Hmmm... What a mystery! Based on the look of the bridesmaids, above, this could possibly be the Brady - Broadhurst wedding in January 1928. It was considered vice-regal as Broadhurst was the Chamberlain to the Governor-General (hence the police presence). There is a description of the bridesmaids' clothing and a photograph of the bride and groom on Trove. nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16433091 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16433188 Also, this photograph is part of the Sam Hood collection, and according to Trove, Hood covered the Brady-Broadhurst wedding... EG
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Thanks quasymody, I checked Pitt Street Congregational and St James Anglican, and it is indeed the latter, where many society weddings are held
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

RW

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: PPPSS - If this were the Brady-Broadhurst wedding, I suspect the bridesmaid on the rhs is Elizabeth Macarthur Onslow...and that we also see her here a few weeks later, in February 1928, with her mother, about to depart Sydney for London on the Narkunda - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=10563 ; see my epic(!) involving the Narkunda here - www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/5444358738/ PPPSSS - I'm now also less convinced that the photographer casting a critical eye in this direction is Harold Cazneaux...looks more like Sam Hood actually www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/4382941931/ ...all these photographers look the same (!) Here's a 1933 SMH pic of Ann(e) Jamieson nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16978803 ?maybe the bridesmaid on the lhs...and a 1931 pic of Rosemary Osborne nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16792455 ?maybe the bridesmaid in the middle...all these bridesmaids look the same (!)

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3903316 this Argus pic of the bride and groom differs slightly from the SMH version...too much has been cropped from the Argus version for it to be helpful! It's a pity the SMH pic of the bride and groom is so dark! nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16433188 ....HOWEVER (!), I've just been looking at the microfilm copy of the SMH...significantly, on the microfilm copy, the image quality is slightly better than the digitised Trove version (I gather the Trove version was scanned from the microfilm copy of the SMH rather than from the original newspaper...so it's at least a 3rd generation image)...on microfilm you can just see that the two white bell like shapes which we see thru the gloom in the Trove version are in fact the policemen's helmets...on microfilm, the policeman on the rhs even appears faintly thru the gloom! ...of course, the other matching clue is little girl on the lhs...in the SMH pic she looks to be wearing the same dress and shoes as we see above...and on microfilm you can see she's taken her hat off and appears to be holding it in her right hand...and she's also pulled up her sock...I suspect this pic might be even clearer in the actual paper copy of the SMH...but as far as I'm concerned there's just enough detail visible in microfilm version of the SMH pic of the bride and groom to settle the issue beyond reasonable doubt...so after 13 months of drawing blanks on this one, I'm now about 95+ % convinced that this SLNSW pic was taken at the Brady-Broadhurst wedding...and I'm also about 90% convinced that Elizabeth Macarthur Onslow is the bridesmaid on the rhs...and that we also see her (with her mother) in the pics taken on the Narkunda a few weeks later (link above)...just who took this SLNSW pic might be something to consider further...the more I look, the more I'm convinced that Sam Hood is the photographer we see casting a critical eye in this direction www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/4382941931/ ...maybe Ted Hood (Sam's son) was also at the wedding... news.google.com/newspapers?id=CA1iAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UfMDA... over at Google News Archive, they appear to have made their scan from the actual paper copy of the SMH...so the image quality is slightly better than the Trove version...though it's still not quite as good as the microfilm version...
